thread.title: Australia government says banking executives responsible for misconduct could face jail

title: Australia government says banking executives responsible for misconduct could face jail
text:
April 18, 2018 / 4:00 AM / Updated 25 minutes ago Australia government says banking executives responsible for misconduct could face jail Reuters Staff 3 Min Read 
SYDNEY (Reuters) - Australian Treasurer Scott Morrison warned on Wednesday that financial sector executives responsible for widespread breaches of corporate law could face jail, as a powerful judicial inquiry heard more evidence of misconduct by the country’s top financial institutions. Australian Treasurer Scott Morrison speaks to the press at Parliament House in Canberra, Australia, May 9, 2017 on the day Australia's federal budget is unveiled. AAP/Dean Lewins/via REUTERS 
Morrison’s comments were made after executives for AMP Ltd ( AMP.AX ), Australia’s largest wealth manager, admitted on Tuesday that employees had lied to the corporate regulator for almost a decade to cover its practise of charging thousands of customers for services they did not provide. 
In further testimony to the so-called Royal Commission on Wednesday, AMP executives admitted that it had charged users of online platforms for advice fees despite not receiving the permission required by law. Slideshow (2 Images) 
“What has occurred here and what has been admitted to in the Royal Commission by AMP is deeply disturbing,” Morrison told reporters on Wednesday. “This type of behaviour can attract penalties which include jail time. That is how serious these things are.” 
The government-backed Royal Commission into Australia’s banking sector is just a couple of months into what is expected to be a year-long investigation and public grilling of senior executives in the country’s financial sector. 
The centre-right government agreed to call the inquiry after years of scandals in Australia’s financial sector, including interest-rate rigging, accusations that some institutions withheld legitimate insurance payouts, and accusations of money-laundering. 
It is currently focussing on the provision of financial advice by AMP and the four largest banks: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group ( ANZ.AX ), Commonwealth Bank of Australia ( CBA.AX ), National Australia Bank ( NAB.AX ) and Westpac Banking Corp ( WBC.AX ). 
In coming months, the inquiry will turn its attention to large insurers and pension funds. Reporting by Paulina Duran; Editing by Jane Wardell and Muralikumar Anantharaman
